Award.AwardTitle: Journey to the Centre of Stars: Testing Stellar Evolution with Asteroseismology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This work will use asteroseismic data of stellar pulsations to test models of stellar evolution. As part of this effort, Dr. Basu and a postdoctoral associate will test whether the internal structure and underlying physics of the most stellar evolution theory is correct. Dr. Basu will also use asteroseismology data to obtain masses, radii, effective temperatures, helium abundances, log g(surface gravity) and convection zone sizes in stars. In particular, her team will use data on the large separation and frequency of maximum oscillation for numerous stars provided by the Kepler Asteroseismic Science Consortium to determine how gross properties of the models should vary across the HR diagram.

This work will extend well beyond stellar astrophysics because stars are used to calibrate both time and distance scales in the Universe and if the stellar models are incorrect, this would have many cosmological implications. This will also involve the training of a postdoctoral research associate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most observations of stars only tell us about the characteristics of their surface --- the temperature, the brightness and  the composition. The interiors of stars cannot be studies directly through such observations. One must rely on theoretical  models to determine other properties of these stars. Observations from the Kepler mission however, are somewhat different.  These observations allow us to detect pulsations in stars. Most stars, including the Sun, pulsate. The properties of the  pulsations depend on the interior properties of the stars, the very properties that conventional observations cannot  determine. These pulsations give us a window into the interior of stars. The investigation carried out under this grant  involved the study of stars using these pulsations.

The investigation could be divided into two categories. The first category of work involved determining how seismic data  could be used to determine properties of stars in the most optimal way possible. This then allowed us to identify some of   the factors that cause uncertainties widely used models of stars. The second category of work involved using seismic data  to actually determine properties of stars, The most interesting part of this work was studying the properties of exp-planet hosts. Our analyses has allowed us to determine that the  exp-planet system Kepler-444 is ancient, 11 billion years old.   This is the oldest known exo-planet system. We were also able to determine the precise size of the the star Kepler-37,   which then allowed us to show that one of its planets, Kepler-37b, is smaller than Mercury.

All results obtained from this investigation have been published in peer-reviewed publications.


The results from this grant affect other fields of astronomy, such as the study of exo-planetary systems, as well as the   history of how our Galaxy formed.

The grant was used to partially support three graduate students and a post-doctoral researcher.
